ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 1. The readings enhanced my understanding of different indigenous silvicultural systems. I especially enjoyed the Tembawang system in Kalimanthan, Indonesia. Learning about the indigenous communities and their appreciation for nature was very humbling. After taking this course, I learned the importance of slash burn systems that were previously thought to be linked to environmental degradation.
Despite the theoretically interesting material, this class was SO BORING. Mostly because the lectures were all delivered directly from the notes.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: All the topics of this class were really interesting.
Chuck Peters is really great!
The readings provided by the professor.
Chuck gave us a great overview of the different indigenous silvicultural practices which I think will help me in the field later on.
different perspective. should be required.
A unique course offering that serves as an essential counter-point to established silvicultural and environmental management practices
The course material is interesting, as are most of the readings.

The topic of indigenous silviculture is largely ignored in academia, and I feel extremely grateful to have been able to take a course that helps me appreciate indigenous peoples and their extraordinary knowledge bases. Dr. Peter's teaching style is different from many other teachers at FES, and I found this really refreshing. He speaks extremely candidly about his experiences and opinions, which I thought was fascinating. He's extremely open to student participation, which greatly helped my learning process. His lectures have an ideal mix of large concepts and actual examples in the field, many of which are his own personal experiences.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: It will be great to have a field trip component in the next class.
more discussion, less lecture
Field trips would have made the case/class material come alive
The lecture style is SO DRY. Lectures are read directly off notes, which makes them really boring.
It might have been interesting to have one lecture that talks about REDD(+) or other global trends/policies that are currently affecting indigenous peoples and their practice of silviculture.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Understing indigenous silviculture practices is one of the most important things that foresters keep in mind to make a better forest management decisions. This class was all about it.
This course provides an important perspective on how landscapes should be managed for both conservation and economic / social gains.

For someone like myself who is interested in working in developing countries, this course gives an idea about the depth of knowledge of people in those countries. Learning about local knowledge and their ability to work with nature is important prior to doing any conservation and development and management works.

This course was a great fit for me. I am interested in sustainable forestry in Latin America, and this course gave me a much need view on the indigenous practices that have long existed in this region and how development activities have and may continue to threaten these activities. Having taken this course, I will go forward in my career with a much greater sensitivity and appreciation for local knowledge and practices.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Recomendations from friends.
I really wanted to take a class taught by Chuck Peters as his interests in non-timber forest products strictly aligns with mine.
I took this course to learn about basic indigenous silvicultural operations.
Personal and business interest - a passion for sustainability and an appreciation for the wisdom and practicality of indigenous traditions
Because I though the material sounded very interesting.

Being interested in sustainable forestry in Latin America, I felt that I should have an exposure to indigenous silviculture practices. Also, I took Dr. Ashton's Applied Silviculture course this semester, and it was a fascinating balance to get both Dr. Peter's and Dr. Ashton's views of silviculture at the same time.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: I learned lot of things that I have never heard about. This class broadened my point of view toward silviculture practices.
Yes!
Yes they definitely do.
Yes
By in large, yes
Really, it was a lot of stuff that I knew more or less before, but this time with a more specific focus on silvicultural practices.

Yes, I learned an enormous amount about indigenous silviculture, but even more importantly, about the global context that indigenous peoples have been in/are currently in and how the international development community has not respected indigenous peoples' knowledge as it should.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Rather than just trying to memorize what professor says, we need to learn how to develop our point about indigenous silviculture throuout the class.

This course teaches you about humility and the importance of participatory research. I will highly recommend it for students who are thinking about doing forestry issues in developing countries as this course exposes students to different indigenous communities who have depths of knowledge.
Sometimes it may seem like Chuck is a slow lecturer but if you really listen to him, he has a lot of knowledge to impart and jokes -- so listen well.
Take good notes
This is an intro course to a fascinating area of study - for those who wish to work in forestry in the developing world, I consider it essential

Unless you are REALLY into indigenous silviculture, this class is really boring, frankly. Not because the material is boring , but because Chuck is a super dry lecturer. He's brilliant, and really into the subject, but just doesn't make the kind of dynamic connection between students and the material that you would want.
I would read as many of the readings as you have time to read. They were helpful in getting a closer look at many indigenous silviculture systems and the concepts discussed in class.
